content.definition: A clinical syndrome resulting from extrinsic compression of the celiac artery by the median arcuate ligament of the diaphragm, causing postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, and weight loss. MALS is a diagnosis of exclusion after ruling out other causes of mesenteric ischemia and abdominal pain.

median_arcuate_ligament: Normally crosses aorta above celiac origin
In MALS: crosses at or below celiac origin

pathophysiology.neurogenic_hypothesis: Compression of celiac plexus causes pain
pathophysiology.controversy: Many asymptomatic patients have celiac compression

cta_mra: Hook-shaped compression of celiac at origin
duplex_with_respiration: Elevated peak systolic velocity in celiac

approach: Open via midline or left subcostal
technique: Confirm adequate celiac flow after release

adjunctive_revascularization: If residual stenosis after ligament release

clinical_pearls: MALS is a DIAGNOSIS OF EXCLUSION
Classic patient: young thin woman with postprandial pain
Hook-shaped celiac compression on CTA (lateral view)
Laparoscopic ligament release is standard treatment
Only 60-80% symptom improvement - may have misdiagnosis
